segment.source: This article builds on concepts and code discussed in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture, which describes the steps for implementing basic photo and video capture.
segment.target: This article builds on concepts and code discussed in Capture Photos and Video with MediaCapture, which describes the steps for implementing basic photo and video capture.

segment.source: Video stabilization effect
segment.target: Video stabilization effect

segment.source: The video stabilization effect manipulates the frames of a video stream to minimize shaking caused by holding the capture device in your hand.
segment.target: The video stabilization effect manipulates the frames of a video stream to minimize shaking caused by holding the capture device in your hand.

segment.source: Because this technique causes the pixels to be shifted right, left, up, and down, and because the effect can't know what the content just outside the video frame is, the stabilized video is cropped slightly from the original video.
segment.target: Because this technique causes the pixels to be shifted right, left, up, and down, and because the effect can't know what the content just outside the video frame is, the stabilized video is cropped slightly from the original video.

segment.source: A utility function is provided to allow you to adjust your video encoding settings to optimally manage the cropping performed by the effect.
segment.target: A utility function is provided to allow you to adjust your video encoding settings to optimally manage the cropping performed by the effect.

segment.source: On devices that support it, Optical Image Stabilization (OIS) stabilizes video by mechanically manipulating the capture device and, therefore, does not need to crop the edges of the video frames.
segment.target: On devices that support it, Optical Image Stabilization (OIS) stabilizes video by mechanically manipulating the capture device and, therefore, does not need to crop the edges of the video frames.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture device controls for video capture.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture device controls for video capture.

segment.source: Initialize the video stabilization effect
segment.target: Initialize the video stabilization effect

segment.source: After your MediaCapture object has been initialized, create a new instance of the VideoStabilizationEffectDefinition object.
segment.target: After your MediaCapture object has been initialized, create a new instance of the VideoStabilizationEffectDefinition object.

segment.source: Call MediaCapture.AddVideoEffectAsync to add the effect to the video pipeline and retrieve an instance of the VideoStabilizationEffect class.
segment.target: Call MediaCapture.AddVideoEffectAsync to add the effect to the video pipeline and retrieve an instance of the VideoStabilizationEffect class.

segment.source: Specify MediaStreamType.VideoRecord to indicate that the effect should be applied to the video record stream.
segment.target: Specify MediaStreamType.VideoRecord to indicate that the effect should be applied to the video record stream.

segment.source: Register an event handler for the EnabledChanged event and call the helper method SetUpVideoStabilizationRecommendationAsync, both of which are discussed later in this article.
segment.target: Register an event handler for the EnabledChanged event and call the helper method SetUpVideoStabilizationRecommendationAsync, both of which are discussed later in this article.

segment.source: Finally, set the Enabled property of the effect to true to enable the effect.
segment.target: Finally, set the Enabled property of the effect to true to enable the effect.

segment.source: Use recommended encoding properties
segment.target: Use recommended encoding properties

segment.source: As discussed earlier in this article, the technique that the video stabilization effect uses necessarily causes the stabilized video to be cropped slightly from the source video.
segment.target: As discussed earlier in this article, the technique that the video stabilization effect uses necessarily causes the stabilized video to be cropped slightly from the source video.

segment.source: Define the following helper function in your code in order to adjust the video encoding properties to optimally handle this limitation of the effect.
segment.target: Define the following helper function in your code in order to adjust the video encoding properties to optimally handle this limitation of the effect.

segment.source: This step is not required in order to use the video stabilization effect, but if you don't perform this step, the resulting video will be upscaled slightly and therefore have slightly lower visual fidelity.
segment.target: This step is not required in order to use the video stabilization effect, but if you don't perform this step, the resulting video will be upscaled slightly and therefore have slightly lower visual fidelity.

segment.source: Call GetRecommendedStreamConfiguration on your video stabilization effect instance, passing in the VideoDeviceController object, which informs the effect about your current input stream encoding properties, and your MediaEncodingProfile which lets the effect know your current output encoding properties.
segment.target: Call GetRecommendedStreamConfiguration on your video stabilization effect instance, passing in the VideoDeviceController object, which informs the effect about your current input stream encoding properties, and your MediaEncodingProfile which lets the effect know your current output encoding properties.

segment.source: This method returns a VideoStreamConfiguration object containing new recommended input and output stream encoding properties.
segment.target: This method returns a VideoStreamConfiguration object containing new recommended input and output stream encoding properties.

segment.source: The recommended input encoding properties are, if it is supported by the device, a higher resolution that the initial settings you provided so that there is minimal loss in resolution after the effect's cropping is applied.
segment.target: The recommended input encoding properties are, if it is supported by the device, a higher resolution that the initial settings you provided so that there is minimal loss in resolution after the effect's cropping is applied.

segment.source: Call VideoDeviceController.SetMediaStreamPropertiesAsync to set the new encoding properties.
segment.target: Call VideoDeviceController.SetMediaStreamPropertiesAsync to set the new encoding properties.

segment.source: Before setting the new properties, use the member variable to store the initial encoding properties so that you can change the settings back when you disable the effect.
segment.target: Before setting the new properties, use the member variable to store the initial encoding properties so that you can change the settings back when you disable the effect.

segment.source: If the video stabilization effect must crop the output video, the recommended output encoding properties will be the size of the cropped video.
segment.target: If the video stabilization effect must crop the output video, the recommended output encoding properties will be the size of the cropped video.

segment.source: This means that the output resolution will match the cropped video size.
segment.target: This means that the output resolution will match the cropped video size.

segment.source: If you do not use the recommended output properties, then the video will be scaled up to match the initial output size, which will result in a loss of visual fidelity.
segment.target: If you do not use the recommended output properties, then the video will be scaled up to match the initial output size, which will result in a loss of visual fidelity.

segment.source: Handle the video stabilization effect being disabled
segment.target: Handle the video stabilization effect being disabled

segment.source: The system may automatically disable the video stabilization effect if the pixel throughput is too high for the effect to handle or if it detects that the effect is running slowly.
segment.target: The system may automatically disable the video stabilization effect if the pixel throughput is too high for the effect to handle or if it detects that the effect is running slowly.

segment.source: If this occurs, the EnabledChanged event is raised.
segment.target: If this occurs, the EnabledChanged event is raised.

segment.source: The VideoStabilizationEffect instance in the sender parameter indicates the new state of the effect, enabled or disabled.
segment.target: The VideoStabilizationEffect instance in the sender parameter indicates the new state of the effect, enabled or disabled.

segment.source: The VideoStabilizationEffectEnabledChangedEventArgs has a VideoStabilizationEffectEnabledChangedReason value indicating why the effect was enabled or disabled.
segment.target: The VideoStabilizationEffectEnabledChangedEventArgs has a VideoStabilizationEffectEnabledChangedReason value indicating why the effect was enabled or disabled.

segment.source: Note that this event is also raised if you programmatically enable or disable the effect, in which case the reason will be Programmatic.
segment.target: Note that this event is also raised if you programmatically enable or disable the effect, in which case the reason will be Programmatic.

segment.source: Typically, you would use this event to adjust your app's UI to indicate the current status of video stabilization.
segment.target: Typically, you would use this event to adjust your app's UI to indicate the current status of video stabilization.
